description.narrative: All COSACA partners have categorized this emergency in the highest category. This means that emergency response support teams are mobilized for support both for short term technical support . Recognizing the immense remaining gaps in the days since Idai struck, COSACA started responding providing affected communities with NFIs and distributing WaSH kits, but on a small scale utilizing COSACA#s prepositioned contingency stocks. Additional resources are required to scale up response activities to meet emerging needs. COSACA through CARE will distribute NFI kits consisting of blanket, solar lantern, system with battery or table lamp, cooking pots, glassfor tea, bowl, tea pot, spoon, peeling knife, soap (toilet), jerry can, match box (pack), big spoon for serving, plastic mat. Thesekits have been developed based on assessed needs and are in line with the Shelter and NFI sector recommendations and the governmentof Mozambique. Special arrangements will be made for individual beneficiaries who are unable toreach the NFI distribution points, including delivery of NFIs for disabled and elderly persons, if needed. As a result of the storms, families fled with few positions. They have been left with very few household materials. While partners are offering food and basic shelter materials; without cookingsupplies and basic kitchen materials these resources cannot be used. These kits will compound the impact of materials offered by other programs and partners and enable households to be more self-sufficient.

participating-org.narrative: CARE International in Mozambique CARE International in Mozambique

CARE International in Mozambique CARE began its operations in Mozambique in 1986 in response to the needs of people affected by theprotracted civil war. During 1986-1990, CARE worked to strengthen its capacity to respond to emergencies and conducted alarge fooddistribution program. From 1990 to 1994, CARE continued its food distribution activities while expanding its portfolio to include development projects. Heavy rains caused by cyclones in 2000 prompted CARE to mount an emergency response to help flood victims. This response included providing temporary shelter and water supplies, managing camps for displaced persons, and distributing small grants to help families recover from their losses. In 2001, CARE responded to flood emergency in Maputo.In 2008, CARE responded to Cyclone Jokwe and the floods in Govuro District with temporary shelter and WASH interventions. CARE implements several major projects in the water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH), agriculture and natural resource management, sexual and reproductive health rights, and land rights sectors. CARE is focusing on poor rural small holder female farmers and adolescent girls who are heavily dependent on land and natural resources.
